reviewText:
Battlefield: Bad Company 2   Field  Rating  Review    Graphics  9  A beautifully rendered world, extremely satisfying levels of destruction, grand animations, and an easy to understand interface. Battlefield: Bad Company 2 has it all.    Gameplay  9  At times, it feels like there are some frustrating balance issues. But those are few and far between. Bad Company 2 is a fantastic game to pick up and go to town with. You'll find glee in causing buildings to crumble around you, planting that charge of C4 on a tank and blowing it up, nailing that perfect headshot from across the map. However, where Bad Company 2 really shines is when you log on with some friends and get coordinated. Communicate and work together to outgun, outflank, and outdo the enemy team.    Story  4  I'll be honest with you. If you are playing Battlefield games for the story, you're going to be really, really disappointed. While there is a storymode here, it honestly isn't worth much of your time except as a glorified tutorial. The characters do give a few good laughs though.    Multiplayer  10  As mentioned earlier, Bad Company 2 really shines when you play with friends, but even alone you're going to have a blast with this one. Hours and hours of fun and destruction await you, with several different modes of multiplayer available to choose from. Be warned though, if you join up this late in the game you're going to face some very, very good long-time players.    Replayability  9  You're going to keep coming back to this one. The peak of the Battlefield series so far, it never gets old racing out of a building as it crumbles around you, covering your team on a withdrawal from an overrun area, or being at the front of a charge to capture a point. Don't miss out on one of the most enjoyable Battlefield experiences yet. The only struggle here is that most your friends will probably have moved on to the new battlefields.    Overall  9.2/10  Though not as popular as it once was (due to the new battlefields) Bad Company 2 still stands at the top of the Battlefield mountain. The Frostbite engine really shines in this iteration. Multiplayer is fast-paced, brutal, and spectacularly fun. Don't like those trees? Mow them down with your LMG. Don't like that building? Blow it up. Your team being overrun? Call in an artillery strike and give them some relief. All in all, an absolute must have for any Battlefield fan.

Battlefield : Bad Company 2 might be the only current-gen/next-gen Battlefield game to not be stained by EA greediness. Just wait before the franchise turns into a free-to-play game with microtransactions and before it invades the Android platform.

The community is still active even nowadays. And yet the game is still the most overlooked Battlefield of the franchise.

PROS :
+Very arcadish gameplay that features unrealistic shooting mechanics and lots of destroyable buildings
+Doesn't require Origin to play
+Ingame servers browser and matchmaking system (no web browsing à la BF3 BF4)
+No premium account, season pass or whatever you call it
+No multiplayer map packs à la Call of Duty, feels like a complete game by itself
+No unlock purchase
+A fun singleplayer campaign (not excellent but nonetheless good)
+One amazing DLC that feels like a Total Conversion or a reskin of Battlefield in the Vietnam War era

CONS :
-No 64 players maps
-No option to change the narrow field of view (default 65) except in the .ini document
-Unlike Battlefield 2, Bad Company 2 features no mod
-Bad Company 2 Vietnam servers are almost empty (if you're lucky you may find two active servers)

Old doesn't mean obsolete!
Forget about Battlefield 3 and 4 and be part of the Bad Company!

P.S.: Don't mistake me. BF3 and BF4 are quite fun. I just dislike the marketing philosophy behind it. I haven't played BF Hardline yet so I can't say anything about it.

reviewText: The best multiplatform shooter. Whereas CoD has you sprinting off by yourself, drop-shotting, and camping with some twitch-shoot mechanics. Battlefield encompasses the features that made people play First Person Shooters to begin with -- the feeling of being in a battle. Several factors contribute to this. The graphics are not the best out there, but they're very solid, much better than the first Bad Company which suffered from a grainy effect and low view-distance. Atmospheric effects (sand, debris, smoke) are done brilliantly and are wonderfully varying. One second you can looking down your scope in the desert and see everything laid out clearly. The next, looking in the same exact spot, your vision can be distorted by a rogue burst of wind and sand. The sound quality is even better, arguably unrivaled in gaming. Distant sound occurs a second or two after the event, giving the impression of a larger battle.\nThe campaign is about standard for modern FPSs, which is why I didn't go into detail, but the multiplayer has no equals -- Bad Company really is in its own category.

reviewText:
tl;dr: HIGHLY reccommend getting this game. Ignoring the mediocre campaign and occasional server frustrations, this is probably the best fps I've ever played.

Even though I moved to a rural area and can no longer play it's muliplayer, I still regard this game very highly. If you have the money to spare, I can almost guarantee that you won't be disappointed. I have no idea what the servers are like these days, but back when I played it, the minor hiccup with the punkbuster service was overshadowed by the dedicated server support. Even the campaign is a fun playthrough for the first couple of times.

What it does right: Where to begin. This is what an fps should feel like. The guns are satisfying to shoot, and kills are an amazing gratification in multiplayer. Everything is smooth and works well, with nothing seeming out of balance if you know which situation to use it in. The massive maps and inclusion of vehicles pretty much necessitates that every match of conquest or mcom needs to be a team effort, and makes this easy with the squad system. The endless unlocks and medals in the multiplayer ensure you always have a goal to work for, and make sure you never stick with one playstyle long enough to get bored with it.

The multiplayer was the most fun I think I've ever had with an fps. The maps are always just the right size to ensure that you can't miss out on the action if there's a full lineup on the server, and with all the variables on each map there's never a dull moment, and every match is a different experience.

Moving away from multiplayer, the singleplayer campaign was surprisingly enjoyable as well. The typical 'russians invading the world' plot bores me to death, but with the likeable characters at the forefront, and throwing out the traditional sense of taking everything way too seriously, this campaign was much more enjoyable than others of the same type. Most COD or even later battlefield games just take themselves too seriously, and the constant quips from the characters and such make it so that's never a problem.

What it does wrong: EA has never been very good at dealing with customers, and the punkbuster service is no exception. Not only is it an extra account that has to be logged into every time you want to play multiplayer, but sometimes it doesn't even work for multiple attemtps. It can get really frustrating when I just want to play the game. I've heard it was to curb piracy and hacking in the game, but all it really does is inconvenience the actual paying customers. It wasn't a good design choice, especially if EA stops checking up on the servers entirely. I would hate to see an entire game broken because of the lack of consideration by the publisher, but with who we're talking about, it wouldn't be surprising.

Another complaint might be the campaign. I know I said it was good, but especially on later playthroughs it can get really repetitive at times. The varied locations are nice, but there's really no reason to play through the campaign to find intel or something once you've beaten it once. This game really shines in the multiplayer, but that doesn't mean some features couldn't have been added to the offline side to make it more enjoyable. Like, you know, a skirmish mode to play against bots. That would've been nice. I don't get how earlier games had this, but DICE just decided to stop doing it all of the sudden. It would've been a godsend when the sign in service was acting up.

The campaign could've done with some weapon customization or unlocks or something to make it worth playing more than once anyway.

So overall, it's a really great game in the multiplayer side of things, and even still enjoyable in singleplayer. I would definitely recommend that everyone give it a try. It has definitely been one of the best experiences I've had in the gaming world.

TL;DR at bottom
If you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!

8/10Recommended Purchase

A Night to Rememberhttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=562697316
Bad Company 2 is a first person shooter game created by DICE and published by EA in 2010. The game features both a team-based multiplayer mode and a singleplayer campaign. The singleplayer campaign has you playing as Marlowe, a member of an elite American special ops team. You start the game,however playing as Thomas Wyatt, coincidentally also a member of a U.S special ops team,though this time you play back in the WWII era instead of in the future. You start out going on a secret mission to meet up with a Japanese Scientist who wants to defect and claims to have valuable information on a new super weapon. Things quickly go to hell and your entire team is wiped out after the Japanese discover you and proceed to make you bear witness to the test firing of the weapon,killing you and your team.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=562538348
You begin the real campaign after that and you start playing as Marlowe,though the campaign is in a futuristic setting now instead of the bleak hell of WWII. The campaign features 13 full levels with each one ranging from 10-20ish minutes to complete,with some more long or difficult missions being around 30-40 minutes at most. For the most part the missions are all quite linear,although they give you open fighting grounds to fill with corpses as you make your way to the objectives.If you came to Bad Co. 2 for a story that would blow your socks off you will be suprisingly (or maybe not suprisingly,depending on how you feel about Battlefield) dissappointed. The story isn't poorly made nor is it poorly done at all really. Problems arise when you have a story that is incredibly average and is only being held up by the unparalleled gunplay. When you get into the thick of fighting it's easy to get lost in the heavy smoke of the fresh gunpowder and the whump of your rifle as you mow down entire squads in your quest to save America from Soviet invasion.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=562508176
Into the Fire . . . With Some Help
The campaign may not be anything special but i'll be damned if this isn't one of the most fun MP modes I have played in quite a while. The destructibility is astoundingly fun to play with and actually has some serious strategic value. Enemy sniper hiding behind a window? 40MM Grenade launcher solves that real quick. Enemy soldiers crossing a bridge into your base? Blow that bridge to hell and back! Being able to just destroy pretty much anything at anytime you want is an incredible idea in both the campaign and the multiplayer. The multiplayer itself consists of 5 different game modes each with varying degrees of difficulty. The first one is Conquest,a mode where each team has a set amount of tickets,dying will of course drop this ticket total by 1 per death,and the goal is to drain the other teams tickets before they drain yours. There are also multiple flags you can hold that will give you a constant ticket drain if you hold the majority. Other than that you just need to kill them faster than they can kill you.The next mode is Rush,a gamemode where you have two teams,attackers and defenders each trying to attack or defend multiple M-COM stations respectively. Attackers are tasked with setting C4 charges on the stations then defending them until they explode. Defenders,of course are charged with defending the stations until they finally bring the attackers' ticket count to zero.After that you have Team Deathmatch which,if you have ever played a multiplayer FPS before, just consists two teams each trying to end the game with the most kills. Next you have squad rush which is just normal rush but with no vehicles,smaller maps,and a max of eight players.Finally there's onslaught,a co-op DLC mode where you try to play against AI and capture flags. Vehicles spawn at certain points and there are multiple levels of difficulty to fight against. Generally all the MP modes seem fairly balanced and there were no glaring problems with the mode that I noticed during regular play. The matchmaking system is completely broken and will either not find you a match,even though plenty are available,or it will put you in a match with just yourself; so make sure you just use server browser.The Multiplayer is what you really would be buying this game for as the campaign was pretty much overlooked due to more people wanting MP than SP.

TL;DRAn excellent game for the price. Astoundingly well done MP component with an overwhelmingly average SP campaign. Solid gunplay and unparalled destructability make this a game you wont want to miss.

reviewText:
Where Battlefield 2 was about that slower paced Squad based Teamwork, Battlefield: Bad Company 2 went in the complete opposite direction. Sure if you work as a team you'll overcome and win as you'd expect, but the pace is ramped up and the craziness is all the way up to 11!

The singleplayer campaign has it's moments, but as with any Battlefield game that has a singleplayer campaign it's not what you'll ultimately be buying the game for. It's the multiplayer - as it should be and as it always should be. Whereas the original Bad Company was tongue-in-cheek and entirely selfaware of how over the top the franchise was at times (as well as the FPS genre in a post-Modern Warfare world), Bad Company 2 tones it down slightly (much to my own personal disappointment).
I personally didn't mind the Bad Company spinoff from the Battlefield series, it was it's own thing and that was entirely fine with me. However, it appears as if Bad Company 2 is almost ashamed of it's original brother and returns to a more 'grounded' root, and almost tries to ape Call of Duty: Modern Warfare's fast paced Michael Bay OTT action... while keeping a straight face.
Which is a shame.

However... that's not what you're interested in in this game... to the multiplayer!

The multiplayer aspect offers you almost everything you'd ask for in a Battlefield game - big maps, crazy weapons, tons of Armor and memorible moments of madness. This was one of the first Battlefield games to really try and push the envelope visually as they ramped up the Frostbite Engine to a whole new level of insanity. I remember feeling 'My PC can actually play this?!' to great surprise and glee too.
So don't undersell your PC if you're unsure on the specs. The minimum specs will still give you a good visual experience.

As for the gameplay, I think this was my favourite. I can't really put my finger on what it was exactly, but everything just seemed to work well together. Teamwork, classes, weapons - land mines. Land Mines. C4. Land mines. Airstrike. Land minds. C4...
OK, so it's the explosions. Planting landmines, hiding around the corner and giggling like a Japanese schoolgirl as that big burley tank came lumbering around the corner to go down the narrow street time and time again. Yup, it's the land mines.

Buy this game.

reviewText:
Here's what I remember about the campaign: I couldn't beat it. It was really, really hard. The AI seemed too smart, too capable, too deadly. And then, because Windows 7 64-bit was giving me trouble at the time, I downgraded, switched back to good old Vista, and lo and behold, suddenly, I beat the campaign with no issues. Since then, I have played on Windows 7, which has none of the teething problems it used to, and not experienced this problem.

Weird, right?

I have no explanation for this. None whatsoever.

The campaign is short--you know how people always accuse multiplayer campaigns of being like four hours long? Well, me, I generally play them in two to three times that much. Only a small handful of games have ever proven to me to be super short, and Bad Company 2 is one of them. It's not a particularly well-designed campaign, either. Fun, I guess, but limited.

The multiplayer was where I spent all my time. Never before or since has a game gripped me as much. I'd be willing to argue it's the best multiplayer in the Battlefield series--it doesn't use that stupid web-based Battlelog like BF3 and BF4 do, after all.

Other than a lack of maps--that were eventually added in, a lack of multiplayer modes (people only ever seem to play Rush or Conquest, a far cry from the dozens of multiplayer modes that ship with other games, like Unreal Tournament or Call of Duty), and a frequent re-use of map assets (which were first seen in BFBC1 and reused in BF3), it's just... the best. It's tweaked right, the classes feel balanced, and the maps themselves are my favorites. I wouldn't say everyone should play this game, but I will say that if you like team-based multiplayer shooters, Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is something you'll enjoy.

The Vietnam expansion was pretty cool, by the way.

reviewText: The best Battlefield. The map design is excellent; it prioritizes fun engagements above all else. Maps are largely built around prefab, destructible, 2-3 floor buildings, which buffer the flow of combat and compartmentalize individual encounters. This means that you can actually breathe and make meaningful decisions in between all of the twitch-based watch-every-corner assaults. You know that segment in every battlefield scene where two soldiers duck behind cover and banter, using the moment of calm to rest and survey their surroundings before leaping back out guns blazing? This game is all about that moment. Front lines move back and forth in a perceivable way, you can get caught in epic holdouts with your squad, and buildings take a LOT of damage before they collapse, with each blown-out wall potentially changing your tactics. And despite how dynamic things get, you never burn out. Because you can breathe.\n\nOh, and there are NO JETS, which means that A) Infantry can meaningfully engage every vehicle, B) no player has to  dedicate themself exclusively to countering air units, C) air units are easy to keep track of, and D) air combat remains cover-based and low-flying. The whole battlefield" experience is much more tightly woven together as a result."

reviewText:
Don't mind my few hours on Steam with this game, as I played another 15 hours on the version I have registered on Origin.

Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a 2010 first-person shooter video game developed by EA DICE. Released in 2010, this game still outdoes nearly every single other game out of the Battlefield-series, and nearly no-one knows why.

The singleplayer is one to be played (though it is a little weird... played it 4 or more times and didn't really understood of what was going on), and the multiplayer has become more than friendly to new players, as there are multiple High-XP-servers on which you can unlock all the weapons within about 3 hours, depending on how you play. You do not need to have Origin started in order to play this game, which is another laaaaarge plus-point.

With the Vietnam DLC, it brings a more historical touch to the game, sadly without a singleplayer campaign, which I imagine would have been the cherry on top of the cake.

Being both brutal and atmospheric at once, this game is a must-have for every Battlefield-fan out there, and a game to be played for every non-Battlefield-fan. ;)


Did I already mention that Battlefield: Bad Company 2 does not require Origin? Because it does not. which is pretty cool if you ask me

I bought this game by accident. When it was on 75% sale, I bought 3 or 4 copies of it to resell later for TF2 keys, and then sell them on the steam market for profit (yea, I know that's lame). But instead of buying all of them as gifts, I accidentally bought one copy for myself. And now, when I finally got a new computer and can play it normally, I can say that I don't regret it at all.
I heard a lot of ♥♥♥♥ about EA and origin, so I didn't expect much from this game, yet it turned out to be really addicting and surprisingly fun.

I'm not going to say too much about the campaign because this game is much more multiplayer-oriented. It's pretty good for getting a grasp on how the game mechanics and weapons work, but I didn't like it TOO much. The plot and characters seem ok, but actual combat is a bit frustrating because your squadmates are downright dumb and you'll  have to kill 90% of the bad guys yourself (another reason for that is that they usually wait for YOU to go first and take all the fire while they sit in some cover). Duh, at least they are immortal, because it would be EXTREMELY frustrating if the game would restart when someone from your squad is killed. And finally - the enemies usually outnumber you by 4-5 times, do the US military commanders really expect THAT much from 4 guys? Unlikely.

The multiplayer, on the other hand, is really awesome. You'll probably get stomped in the beginning though, because crucial unlocks for your soldier are received after not too much, but noticable playtime - for instance, in the beginning your medic loadout will be MG+pistol, that's all; medkit and defibrillator is easily unlocked later, but still kinda frustrating when your teammates expect you to throw some first aid at them and you, well, CAN'T. That being said, at least most WEAPONS you get at the start are pretty good, most notably sniper rifle and assault rifle.
The overall balance is great, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ specializations (not meaning to start a flame war, but CoD's martyrdom" comes to mind)

This game was released 2010. That is 6 years ago and we know what EA and Dice has given us after that. A lot of improvements, graphicly, Frostbite engine, Higher tick rate servers etc.

+ Graphic: The graphic is really nice and the gameplay feel very smooth.
+ Storyline: I wish I could have played Bad Company 1 as well because I do believe that it had a better story. However the actors and the comedy make this story to one of a kind. No doubt.

+ Weapons: The weapon FEELS powerful. The sound are really nice.
+ Soundtrack: I really like how they added music to the game. It adds much more feeling to the game.

- Multiplayer unbalanced maps: This problem still remains in Battlefield 3/4 as well. The map are too unbalanced. Which means on some maps, 8/10 times you etheir win hard or lose hard. There is no between. This cannot be blamed on the teams. It is a map issue.

- There is hardly any rest time in multiplayer. When you lose a base in rush. It takes you 10 seconds and then the enemy are nearby the next objective. Very intense and I disslike it. Personal opinion

- During the story line you run a lot. On Battlefield 3/4 they leave you with much more action, less running. I put it as a negative thing however it is a personal preference.

- Story line bugs. There are a lot of them. CPU that won't die. Terrain bugs. etc. It is not something that RUIN the story but everytime it happens. It will remind you that it exist.

I won't compare this game to Battlefield 3/4 so I say as a game in general 8/10

reviewText:
Going back to my favorite first person military shooter franchise, Bad Company 2 is one of the best battlefield games I've ever played. You don't need an Origin account to play, there is no Battlefield Premium, free DLC maps, and the best expansion ever: The Vietnam DLC.

I remember playing the beta for Battlefield: Bad Company 2. Upon it's release for Xbox 360, I've put countless hours into multiplayer with my friends and we had a blast throughout all the modes and maps. Bad Company 2 is still well populated on the PC. The single player campaign is alright, but I liked Bad Company 1's campaign more.

There aren't many cons I can point out about the game.. The Progression system- It takes a bit too long to reach the max rank level 50 in this game, unless you play on modded servers.
No Onslaught mode for PC- This coop mode was so fun on the 360. I'm not sure why this mode was not included for PC.
Now this last one isn't really relevent to the review. No Bad Company 1 port- I liked the original Bad Company just as much, If not, more than Bad Company 2. More classes, classic gold rush, Acta Non Verba, The Legionaire, the humor, golf carts, Serdaristan, and just the classic Bad Company feel. If there is a chance EA can port the first Bad Company to PC, I hope they do it.

Battlefield: Bad Company 2 earns a 9/10. When Bad Company 2 goes on sale, buy it; it's $10

That's my review for Battlefield: Bad Company 2 and I will see you guys on the next review.  Let's form up! ~Stealth 1548

Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a first-person game having both single player and multiplayer modes.

In the campaign you play as 1 of 4 U.S. soldiers and complate missions mainly fighting against Russian forces. Over the course of the game you will shoot shotguns, assault rifles, snipers, man turrets and drive vehicles. Personally the story wasn't that interesting to me, but it got kinda better near the end of it.

Multiplayer has several gamemodes which you can play. The maps are pretty big allowing for not only infantry combat, but also the presence of tanks, helicopters, ATVs and APCs and that differentiates it from other FPS games. You can choose between 4 classes which each specialise in something.

There are usually a couple of servers with players, but most are empty. Sometimes you will get killed by an Apache while at spawn. Vision on lowest graphics at least is kinda bad and the size of the maps doesn't help at all. You can get killed by a hundred different things and you might not even understand what was going on.

I'd recommend this game if its on sale.

reviewText: Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a 2010 first-person shooter video game developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts (EA). It is a direct sequel to Battlefield: Bad Company and is part of the Battlefield game series. The game is primarily a squad-level first-person shooter based in a contemporary modern warfare setting. Additionally, the game includes a single-player campaign, where the player re-assumes the role of Preston Marlowe, the protagonist of the original game. The game's Frostbite 1.5 engine now allows for destructible environments. Multiplayer maps, which allow for five different game modes, contain a wide selection of vehicles, aircraft and emplacements. While Bad Company 2 is primarily a first-person shooter, it follows other games in the series by allowing the player to control certain vehicles, including ATVs, APCs, tanks, and helicopters. On foot, players are given access to a variety of real-world small arms such as assault rifles and machine guns. Players can also jump, crouch, and sprint. Bad Company 2 heavily emphasizes destructible environments. Large sections of most buildings can be destroyed by explosives, and some walls and fences break down under barrages of bullets, with the game's physics engine realistically simulating the destruction. Bad Company 2 features a story-driven single-player campaign. For most of the narrative, the player takes control of Preston Marlowe, one of the members of the titular Bad Company". Multiplayer is class-based

reviewText:
Bad Company 2 is a first person shooter game created by DICE and published by EA in 2010. The game features both a team-based multiplayer mode and a singleplayer campaign. The singleplayer campaign has you playing as Marlowe, a member of an elite American special ops team. You start the game,however playing as Thomas Wyatt, coincidentally also a member of a U.S special ops team,though this time you play back in the WWII era instead of in the future. You start out going on a secret mission to meet up with a Japanese Scientist who wants to defect and claims to have valuable information on a new super weapon. Things quickly go to hell and your entire team is wiped out after the Japanese discover you and proceed to make you bear witness to the test firing of the weapon,killing you and your team.

You begin the real campaign after that and you start playing as Marlowe,though the campaign is in a futuristic setting now instead of the bleak hell of WWII. The campaign features 13 full levels with each one ranging from 10-20ish minutes to complete,with some more long or difficult missions being around 30-40 minutes at most. For the most part the missions are all quite linear,although they give you open fighting grounds to fill with corpses as you make your way to the objectives.If you came to Bad Co. 2 for a story that would blow your socks off you will be suprisingly (or maybe not suprisingly,depending on how you feel about Battlefield) dissappointed. The story isn't poorly made nor is it poorly done at all really. Problems arise when you have a story that is incredibly average and is only being held up by the unparalleled gunplay. When you get into the thick of fighting it's easy to get lost in the heavy smoke of the fresh gunpowder and the whump of your rifle as you mow down entire squads in your quest to save America from Soviet invasion.
6
Into the Fire . . . With Some Help

The campaign may not be anything special but i'll be damned if this isn't one of the most fun MP modes I have played in quite a while. The destructibility is astoundingly fun to play with and actually has some serious strategic value. Enemy sniper hiding behind a window? 40MM Grenade launcher solves that real quick. Enemy soldiers crossing a bridge into your base? Blow that bridge to hell and back! Being able to just destroy pretty much anything at anytime you want is an incredible idea in both the campaign and the multiplayer. The multiplayer itself consists of 5 different game modes each with varying degrees of difficulty. The first one is Conquest,a mode where each team has a set amount of tickets,dying will of course drop this ticket total by 1 per death,and the goal is to drain the other teams tickets before they drain yours. There are also multiple flags you can hold that will give you a constant ticket drain if you hold the majority. Other than that you just need to kill them faster than they can kill you.The next mode is Rush,a gamemode where you have two teams,attackers and defenders each trying to attack or defend multiple M-COM stations respectively. Attackers are tasked with setting C4 charges on the stations then defending them until they explode. Defenders,of course are charged with defending the stations until they finally bring the attackers' ticket count to zero.After that you have Team Deathmatch which,if you have ever played a multiplayer FPS before, just consists two teams each trying to end the game with the most kills. Next you have squad rush which is just normal rush but with no vehicles,smaller maps,and a max of eight players.Finally there's onslaught,a co-op DLC mode where you try to play against AI and capture flags. Vehicles spawn at certain points and there are multiple levels of difficulty to fight against. Generally all the MP modes seem fairly balanced and there were no glaring problems with the mode that I noticed during regular play. The matchmaking system is completely broken and will either not find you a match,even though plenty are available,or it will put you in a match with just yourself; so make sure you just use server browser.The Multiplayer is what you really would be buying this game for as the campaign was pretty much overlooked due to more people wanting MP than SP.

reviewText:
(side note: before this game i only played a small amount of the Battlefield 3 campaign back when it was free for all to grab, i never finished that campaign nor any other BF BC campaign)

As far as i remember i think i picked up this game after hearing how good the games campaign and Multiplayer was when i was with friends, it was laying down in my library for months without my touching it once, but lately I’ve got that good “ol’ shoot everything that moves” mindset in games as of late so i thought let’s give this game a shot, and oh boy was i in for a treat. This is my review of Battlefield Bad Company 2!

You take the roll of Private Preston Marlow. 1 of the 4 guys of the squad Bad Company alongside the pyromania Hags, technerd Sweets and retirement-whining sergeant “Sarge” Redford. But before that, we go back in time during WW2 where you are part of a squad for operation Aurora in October 1944 extracting a Japanese scientist with vital information on a mysterious weapon.

The game plays like your traditional First Person Shooter(FPS for short) but with a little twist compared to the other shooters, thanks to DICE’s FROSTBITE engine you play in areas where you can literally DESTROY your surroundings (buildings at least but it’s still amazing) there is a big amount of weapons at your disposal as you progress the game, you got your classic Assault Rifles, LMG’s Snipers and Shotgun with regular and explosive ammunition.

The looks AMAZING, it has aged extremely well and actually stands up pretty good compared to BF3,4 and Hardline and I’ve encountered no bugs or glitches during my playthrough,

The only complaints I got about the game are the personalities of Marlow and Sarge, Marlow is your generic soldier who doesn’t speak outside of cutscenes and Sarge can be a whiny ♥♥♥♥♥ at times when it comes to his retirement.

This game is a definite Must for any shooter fan with one of the best campaigns i've played in a shooter

reviewText:
The last good Battlefield installment for me.
Starting off with the campaign. It was solid for a game built that was a multiplayer shooter from day one. It's pretty funny and the characters do have a backstory if you played or watched some clips from the first BC installment. It's your usual funny buddy scenario. Four characters with four personalities. You know you can expect some fun!
The destruction in the campaign is as great as it is in the multiplayer, thanks to Frostbite. It looks wonderful even on lower details. The only ♥♥♥♥ thing is the amount of bloom sand and snow have in the game. Besides that, everything is spot on! It took me, like the usual, 6-7 hours for the game but without any of the collectables and whatnot. It has a great campaign for what it is; your multiplayer driven shooter.

The multiplayer is what packs the punch. Servers are still healthy looking even today. As every Battlefield game, it does have it's glorious moments. Wether repair-tooling Recons on Arica Harbor, driving downhill with a tank and losing 40 HP, or getting quad kills with C4 on completely fair and balanced Rush maps. You got your 4 classes with own weapons and gadgets for each situation. Be the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on a hardcore server with Carl Gustav and Explosive MK2, or the 12x .50cal Recon ♥♥♥♥, it's all up to you!
All modes are up and running besides Squad Rush. That mode is dead. For the most fun I would recommend Conquest for some big battles, and Rush for some ♥♥♥♥ and giggles. Never play the map Heavy Metal. No one likes that ♥♥♥♥! Especially on insta-respawn vehicle servers where everyone and their ancestors are flying helicopters.

I'd give it a lovely 9.5/10. Would have been a 10 but it still has tiny problems. Buy it even in 2015. It is never late to join the party!

reviewText:
Graphics
9
A beautifully rendered world, extremely satisfying levels of destruction, grand animations, and an easy to understand interface. Battlefield: Bad Company 2 has it all.
Gameplay
9
At times, it feels like there are some frustrating balance issues. But those are few and far between. Bad Company 2 is a fantastic game to pick up and go to town with. You'll find glee in causing buildings to crumble around you, planting that charge of C4 on a tank and blowing it up, nailing that perfect headshot from across the map. However, where Bad Company 2 really shines is when you log on with some friends and get coordinated. Communicate and work together to outgun, outflank, and outdo the enemy team.
Story
4
I'll be honest with you. If you are playing Battlefield games for the story, you're going to be really, really disappointed. While there is a storymode here, it honestly isn't worth much of your time except as a glorified tutorial. The characters do give a few good laughs though.
Multiplayer
10
As mentioned earlier, Bad Company 2 really shines when you play with friends, but even alone you're going to have a blast with this one. Hours and hours of fun and destruction await you, with several different modes of multiplayer available to choose from. Be warned though, if you join up this late in the game you're going to face some very, very good long-time players.
Replayability
9
You're going to keep coming back to this one. The peak of the Battlefield series so far, it never gets old racing out of a building as it crumbles around you, covering your team on a withdrawal from an overrun area, or being at the front of a charge to capture a point. Don't miss out on one of the most enjoyable Battlefield experiences yet. The only struggle here is that most your friends will probably have moved on to the new battlefields.
Overall
9.2/10
Though not as popular as it once was (due to the new battlefields) Bad Company 2 still stands at the top of the Battlefield mountain. The Frostbite engine really shines in this iteration. Multiplayer is fast-paced, brutal, and spectacularly fun. Don't like those trees? Mow them down with your LMG. Don't like that building? Blow it up. Your team being overrun? Call in an artillery strike and give them some relief. All in all, an absolute must have for any Battlefield fan.

Battlefield, probably one of the best multiplayer games out there. I remember playing Battlefield 1943 on the Xbox 360, thinking that Dice had to make more games like this. and they Did. and they are all great! I also like Battlefield 3/4, But I personally think that BF 3/4 and BF: BC2 is good in their own ways.

Battlefield 3/4's multiplayer is all about the Big wars, 64 players. The feeling of running in Huge maps with 63 other players, hearing jets and choppers fly near, hearing gunshots and explosions all around you, is such a great thrilling experience. You feel like you are in an actual war, unlike COD for an example, where its only like 12 players in a small map.

Battlefield Bad Company 2's Multiplayer is pretty much the same, except with 32 players, and its not as hectic as BF 3/4, but its still fun, and you still get that War feeling. and Yes, there are still lots of people playing this game, lots of servers are still full, as of September 2014. Although I dont think Battlefield Vietnam has much players anymore.

The recommended Gamemode for any of the Battlefield's is Conquest. Conquest is mainly about capturing bases and protecting them from the upcoming enemies and vehicles. Usually the bases are A,B,C,D. It is possible to kill people, not everyone is hard, so you dont have to worry about being a newbie. There are a couple of classes to choose, on BF: BC2, I like the Medic, mainly because of his huge Badass guns, but for games like BF 3/4, I use the Engineer, since there is always tanks roaming around on those games.

There is a Singleplayer story for all the Battlefield's of course, and Probably Bad Company 2's Campaign is the best, because Comedy plus War is a pretty great combination.

Overall, its Battlefield, if you had second thoughts about getting this game, Dont, JUST GET IT! ITS A GREAT GAME AND YOU WONT REGRET GETTING IT! 10/10

reviewText:
Battlefield, probably one of the best multiplayer games out there. I remember playing Battlefield 1943 on the Xbox 360, thinking that Dice had to make more games like this. and they Did. and they are all great! I also like Battlefield 3/4, But I personally think that BF 3/4 and BF: BC2 is good in their own ways.

Battlefield 3/4's multiplayer is all about the Big wars, 64 players. The feeling of running in Huge maps with 63 other players, hearing jets and choppers fly near, hearing gunshots and explosions all around you, is such a great thrilling experience. You feel like you are in an actual war, unlike COD for an example, where its only like 12 players in a small map.

Battlefield Bad Company 2's Multiplayer is pretty much the same, except with 32 players, and its not as hectic as BF 3/4, but its still fun, and you still get that War feeling. and Yes, there are still lots of people playing this game, lots of servers are still full, as of September 2014. Although I dont think Battlefield Vietnam has much players anymore.

The recommended Gamemode for any of the Battlefield's is Conquest. Conquest is mainly about capturing bases and protecting them from the upcoming enemies and vehicles. Usually the bases are A,B,C,D. It is possible to kill people, not everyone is hard, so you dont have to worry about being a newbie. There are a couple of classes to choose, on BF: BC2, I like the Medic, mainly because of his huge Badass guns, but for games like BF 3/4, I use the Engineer, since there is always tanks roaming around on those games.

There is a Singleplayer story for all the Battlefield's of course, and Probably Bad Company 2's Campaign is the best, because Comedy plus War is a pretty great combination.

Overall, its Battlefield, if you had second thoughts about getting this game, Dont, JUST GET IT! ITS A GREAT GAME AND YOU WONT REGRET GETTING IT! 10/10

reviewText: In my opinion this game is currently (2011) the most enjoyable first person shooter on the market. If your computer can handle the graphics (they're intense) than you will not be disappointed. Although there is a single-player campaign, this game is primarily a multiplayer game. The single player campaign is mediocre but enjoyable (nothing like COD's excitement) but the multiplayer is where the game really shines. PROS.
